title-group.article-title: Median Group® in a Psychiatric Outpatient Service and in a Psychiatric Diagnosis and Treatment Service (SPDC)

article-meta.issue-title: De Maré Special Section: Patrick de Maré’s Contribution to Mental Health: Reclaiming the Mind

abstract.p: Outlined is a brief description of two pieces of research into the Median Group experience in an open psychiatric outpatient service and in a closed ward. The first is about the self-definition and well being of 30 patients in three Median Groups, mostly under drug prescription, and 31 patients only under drug prescription. On nine sub scales (five levels each) of SCL (Symptom Check List)-90-R, only the field of somatization shows small differences between the experimental and the control group, whereas in all the others the differences are statistically significant, which means a better quality of life.

The other research has been undertaken by Laura Pozzi, who introduced the Median Group to a closed psychiatric ward of a general hospital. It shows a high level of acceptance within the group, and on the group ward level, a sudden decrease of aggressive episodes has been registered.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: I would briefly describe the outcome regarding the efficacy and satisfaction of the participants of two pieces of research into the Median Group experience in an open psychiatric outpatient service, and in a closed ward (Schöllberger, 2011).

sec.title: Research I
sec.p: With the help of many colleagues in 20051, we finished a piece of research about the self-definition of well being of 30 patients in three Median Groups, mostly under drug prescription, and 31 patients only under drug prescription.
The diagnosis represents a range from mid disturbances to severe psychiatric diseases in both male and female, who were quite equally divided by language.

The patients of the experimental group obtain more benefits in relief from suffering than the group of patients which take only prescribed drugs. On nine sub scales (five levels each) of SCL (Symptom Check List)-90-R (Franke, 1995), only the field of somatization shows small differences between the experimental and the control group (see figure 1).

sec.title: Research II
sec.p: The other research was undertaken by Laura Pozzi (Pozzi, 2008) who introduced the Median Group to a closed psychiatric ward of a general hospital2.

The Median Group has run weekly since 2006 and it has carried out research for eight months on the appreciation of the group sessions by the patients, using the Appreciation Inventory by Jagher (Jagher, 2006)3.

It shows a high acceptance within the group where the participants found the group a positive experience, i.e. 78%, negative; 10.5% and 11.5% neither positive nor negative. A positive feeling after the group sessions was displayed by 58%, indifferent 15%, perplexed 14%, anxiety 10% and 2.5% did not answer to this question.

On the group ward level there was a decrease of aggressive episodes. In fact, the introduction of the Median Group in the closed psychiatric ward was caused by the high rate (53) of violent behaviour during the four month period (between June and October 2006) before the Median Group was started; decreasing to 29 until December and to six episodes from January to March 2007 (see figure 2).

Therefore, there is no basis for fears that free discussion could be a danger or make trouble for participants. On the contrary, it seems that engagement in dialogue has had some influence on the closed ward culture: a humanization process.

fn.p: The research has been undertaken by Roberto Schoellberger, Rodolfo Tommasi, Fernando Biague, Franca de Pasquale, Oskar Giovanelli, Eliana Maretti 2005

Since 1978, there are no longer asylums in Italy (apart from the Justice Hospitals which will be closed within 2013); there are instead psychiatric closed wards for 14–20 patients within the other wards in the general hospital and in most regions a good organized psychiatric community service. In some of them they keep the closed psychiatric ward open.

Dialogue Group Appreciation Inventory in Borgo Valsugana SPDC. The questionnaire is a tool developed by the working group of the Psychiatric Diagnosis and Treatment Service of Borgo Valsugana with the objective of evaluating the views of practitioners and patients about the level of usefulness of this activity and what is the level of involvement of respondents. The questionnaire was proposed to patients (no. 85) who took part in group meetings during October 2007 to May 2008, and to practitioners (no.20) in work at the service (medical, nursing, caring and rehabilitation). (Data processed by Giuseppina Castiello-TeRP-SPDC Borgo V., Denart Professional Nurse, SPDC Borgo V. )

bio.p: Roberto Schoellberger is a psychoanalyst, currently in private practice. He is a training analyst at the Institut für Psychoanalyse Zürich (CH), International Federation Psychoanalytic Societies-IFPS member, Full Member GAS (London), and member of COIRAG (Italy) Il Cerchio, Rome. He is President of Group Analytic Association ‘Patrick de Maré, Bolzano (Italy). He has worked with Psichiatria Democratica, the movement that helped to close asylums and make community psychiatry possible in Italy. Supervisor of teamwork in clinical and social psychology, teaching group therapy at Centro Ricerche e Psicoterapia-CeRP, Trento (Italy), he also leads training sessions in group therapy and group work. Address: Corso Libertà 53, 39100 Bolzano, Italy. Email: koinonie@tiscali.it

Laura Pozzi is a physician and works in a psychiatric closed ward (SPDC) of S. Lorenzo’s Hospital in Borgo Valsugana (Trento) Italy where she has held a Dialogue Group (Median Group) for inpatients since 2006. She attends the Group Analysis Supervision Median Group organized from the SIP (Italian Society of Psychiatry) by Roberto Schoellberger. From 2011 she also leads a Dialogue Group for parents of patients of the Therapeutic Community ‘Il Rododendro’ in Levico Terme (Trento). Email: laura.pozzi@apss.tn.it
